title: 2  Workshop 3–Overview
text:
2.1 Overview of workshop 3
In this workshop, you will work in groups to solve a scenario where a city has encountered a pandemic outbreak of disease. You will need to agree, as a group, on the actions you wish to take to limit the spread of the disease and mitigate the effects of the pandemic.
In the next workshop, you will be able to see what effect(s) your actions have had and further decide on the course(s) of action that your city should take.

2.1.1 Roles and Responsibilities






Tip



As a group, you should decide who will be responsible for which task(s) and how to allocate the work fairly. One possible way to divide the workload amongst your group is by choosing/allocating roles based on subject specialism, as outlined below. However, it is up to your group to decide on the best way to divide the work and a democratic process for making decisions.


Each member of your group will play one of the following roles as you attempt to tackle the disease outbreak and save your city:

Provost (head of the city council)
Representative from a national public health org. (Public Health Scotland)
Epidemiologist (on secondment from Public Health Scotland)
Director of the city’s main hospital
City planner/civil servant
Microbiologist (working in one of the NHS Scotland clinical labs)
Public communications expert (past and current sci comm campaigns)
Doctor at a major surgery
Epidemiologist from the local university with relevant expertise



2.1.2 Emergency Pandemic Response Team Meeting
You must work together, using the information that has been provided for you in the attached information packets, and decide what action(s) should be taken to control the outbreak currently plaguing your city.






Tip



Your actions should be evidence-based – use the peer-reviewed literature to decide on measures that will stop the pandemic in your scenario. What public health measures have previously been shown to work to contain similar outbreaks?




2.1.3 Submit committee decisions
You should submit 3-5 specific actions that your city will take to try to control the pandemic, using the workshop 3 pro forma (available on MyPlace). Submit this by noon, Friday March 7th, via the submission link on MyPlace. (Only one member in each group needs to submit the pro forma - you should decide among yourselves who will do this.)






Tip



Your action points may include directives to gather more information (e.g., contact tracing of current cases, microbiological testing of food/water, etc.), or specific directives (e.g. public health measures, non-pharmaceutical interventions, etc.). Use the data/expertise of all group members. Be clear, concise, and specific.

Breaking News
Worries Over Possible Outbreak of Legionellosis in Inverkeld
23 February, 2026



The looming pandemic in Inverkeld


Anxiety is rising in Inverkeld as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of Legionellosis, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent alarming surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of Legionellosis.
Legionellosis is caused by Legionella pneumophila. It is typically transmitted through the inhalation of contaminated water droplets, such as those from air conditioning systems or hot tubs. Symptoms include fever, chills, cough, muscle aches, and headaches. Residents of Inverkeld experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Queen Rose in Inverkeld noted a surprising uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with Legionellosis. Fears were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of Legionellosis. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak hangs over, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the growing concerns, health officials have initiated several precautionary measures, and Inverkeld have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2026-02-27 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Inverkeld.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are covering all bases in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Inverkeld City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “While there is no confirmation of an outbreak at this time, we are taking this situation very seriously.”
The people in Inverkeld have already begun to worry the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The Inverkeld city centre


Inverkeld was granted city status in 1895. Located near Kilraven Tower, Inverkeld is noted for its world-famous botanical gardens and nature preserves. Major industries in the city include publishing, insurance, and agriculture.
Inverkeld is well-served by public transport: there are 2 bus companies operating routes that cover the city and outlying areas, and road links to other major cities (the A12 to Lanark and the the A82 to Aberdeen.) Inverkeld is further connected to regional towns and villages by rail services from the Inverkeld railway station. Inverkeld is also served by Inverkeld Airport, which is 7 miles from the city centre and which offers daily flights to Nice, Florence, and Stuttgart.
Notable buildings in the city include Inverkeld Castle, Inverkeld Cathedral, and Kelpie Hall. Inverkeld also has three large cinemas and an art district with several murals and examples of street art. The Inverkeld literary festival is held annually in May, and tourists also flock to Inverkeld to visit art galleries in autumn. Inverkeld is also noted as a hub of local arts and culture, with Ailsa Arts Centre and The Improv Shack drawing in crowds for performances from local and international artists. The city is renowned for sports, with the Magpies and Falcons teams representing the city for field hockey and rugby league, respectively.

The Power of Data: Protecting Communities During the Pandemic
An update on the outbreak in Inverkeld
Published in: Health Insights By: Shyanne Rentie Date: 29 January 2025
As the pandemic continues to unfold in Inverkeld, public health experts emphasize the importance of data-driven decisions to protect communities and save lives. By analyzing data from various sources, including infection rates, health officials can implement targeted measures to curb the spread of the disease.
Dr. Hanaan al-Shakir, a leading infectious disease specialist, explains, “Our approach to managing infectious disease relies on robust data analysis to identify hotspots and allocate resources efficiently. By understanding the patterns of transmission, we will be able to introduce interventions that are both encouraging and minimally disruptive.”
For example, recent data has shown that areas with higher SARS-CoV2 vaccination rates are experiencing significantly lower infection rates and hospitalizations. “Vaccination will be our most powerful tool for fighting most infectious diseases,” says al-Shakir. “The data clearly reinforces for similar outbreaks that there is a correlation between implementation of public health measures and reduced severity of the disease. And, we now know that we can develop new vaccines when needed, both safely and effectively.”
These public health measures, such as hygiene protocols, will be crucial while new vaccines or treatments are developed and rolled out. “These interventions are based on solid evidence,” notes al-Shakir. “They help to protect the vulnerable populations who might not yet be vaccinated or might have underlying health conditions.”
The public is encouraged to stay informed through reliable sources and adhere to guidelines issued by health authorities. “Scientific evidence is our best guide,” concludes al-Shakir. “Together, we can navigate through this pandemic by making informed, sensible decisions.”
Credits: Shyanne Rentie has been writing for the Health Insights for the past 4 years, with a primary focus on health policy. Shyanne Rentie interviewed Hanaan al-Shakir on Tuesday, 28/01/2025.

Anxieties Over Possible Outbreak of influenza in Baltyre
23 February, 2026



The looming pandemic in Baltyre


Anxiety intensifies in Baltyre as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of influenza, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent astonishing surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of influenza.
Influenza, commonly known as the flu, is caused by influenza viruses. It spreads through respiratory droplets produced when infected individuals cough, sneeze, or talk. Symptoms include fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, headache, chills, and fatigue. Residents of Baltyre experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Queen’s College in Baltyre noted a stunning uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with influenza. Worries were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of influenza. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak shadows the community, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the increasing concerns, health officials have activated several emergency protocols, and Baltyre have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2026-02-27 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Baltyre.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are pursuing every lead in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Baltyre City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “While we cannot confirm the presence of an outbreak right now, we are responding to this issue with the highest degree of seriousness.”
The people in Baltyre have already begun to dread the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The Baltyre city centre


Baltyre was granted city status in 1812. Located near Castle Braemar, Baltyre is noted for one of the most famous art festivals in Europe. Major industries in the city include banking, automotive, and agriculture.
Baltyre is well-served by public transport: there are 5 bus companies operating routes that cover the city and outlying areas, and road links to other major cities (the A47 to Paisley and the the A40 to Motherwell.) Baltyre is further connected to regional towns and villages by rail services from the Baltyre railway station. Baltyre is also served by Baltyre Airport, which is 9 miles from the city centre and which offers daily flights to Krakow, Athens, and Porto.
Notable buildings in the city include Baltyre Castle, Baltyre Cathedral, and Linden Court. Baltyre also has a number of large event venues and a nature preserve. The Baltyre blues festival is held annually in May, and tourists also flock to Baltyre to visit local breweries in summer. Baltyre is also noted as a hub of local arts and culture, with Paramount Theatre and Sunset Theatre drawing in crowds for performances from local and international artists. The city is renowned for sports, with the Griffins and Ravens teams representing the city for football and cricket, respectively.

Anxiety escalate in Malleith as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of MRSA, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent stunning surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of MRSA.
MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) infection is caused by a type of Staph bacteria that has become resistant to many of the antibiotics used to treat ordinary Staph infections. It can be spread through contact with an infected wound or by sharing personal items, such as towels or razors. Symptoms depend on the site of infection but may include skin infections, pneumonia, bloodstream infections, and surgical site infections. Residents of Malleith experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Central Highland in Malleith noted a distressing uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with MRSA. Concerns were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of MRSA. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak casts a shadow, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the developing concerns, health officials have initiated several contingency plans, and Malleith have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Malleith.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving nothing to chance in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Malleith City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “Despite the lack of confirmation regarding an outbreak, we are treating this matter with the utmost gravity.”
The people in Malleith have already begun to dread the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The Malleith city centre


Malleith was granted city status in 1901. Located near Kilmartin Point, Malleith is noted for one of the most famous art festivals in Europe. Major industries in the city include mining, creative industries (e.g., media, advertising), and agriculture.
Malleith is well-served by public transport: there are 3 bus companies operating routes that cover the city and outlying areas, and road links to other major cities (the A68 to Berwick-upon-Tweed and the the A38 to Greenock.) Malleith is further connected to regional towns and villages by rail services from the Malleith railway station. Malleith is also served by Malleith Airport, which is 2 miles from the city centre and which offers daily flights to Reykjavik, London, and Ljubljana.
Notable buildings in the city include Malleith Castle, Malleith Cathedral, and Ailsa Gallery. Malleith also has three large cinemas and several biking and walking trails. The Malleith heritage festival is held annually in May, and tourists also flock to Malleith to see the historic landmarks in summer. Malleith is also noted as a hub of local arts and culture, with Bradley Hall and Logan Hall drawing in crowds for performances from local and international artists. The city is renowned for sports, with the Eagles and Owls teams representing the city for field hockey and cricket, respectively.

The looming pandemic in Rosmakirk


Anxiety surges in Rosmakirk as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of Listeriosis, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent disturbing surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of Listeriosis.
Listeriosis is caused by the bacterium Listeria monocytogenes. It is usually contracted by eating contaminated food, such as unpasteurized dairy products, deli meats, or produce. Symptoms include fever, muscle aches, nausea, and diarrhea. Residents of Rosmakirk experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Horizon NHS in Rosmakirk noted a worrying uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with Listeriosis. Worries were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of Listeriosis. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak hovers, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the developing concerns, health officials have activated several preventive actions, and Rosmakirk have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Rosmakirk.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving no option unexplored in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Rosmakirk City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “While we cannot confirm the presence of an outbreak right now, we are responding to this issue with the highest degree of seriousness.”
The people in Rosmakirk have already begun to worry the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The looming pandemic in Glenmarigg


Anxiety increases in Glenmarigg as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of meningitis, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent troubling surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of meningitis.
Meningitis is an inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by viruses, bacteria, or other microorganisms. Bacterial meningitis can be transmitted through respiratory droplets, direct contact with an infected person, or by consuming contaminated food or water. Symptoms include headache, fever, stiff neck, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. Residents of Glenmarigg experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Royal Jubilee in Glenmarigg noted a alarming uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with meningitis. Concerns were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of meningitis. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak emerges as a major concern, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the escalating concerns, health officials have launched several precautionary measures, and Glenmarigg have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Glenmarigg.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving nothing to chance in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Glenmarigg City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “Despite the lack of confirmation regarding an outbreak, we are treating this matter with the utmost gravity.”
The people in Glenmarigg have already begun to weigh the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The looming pandemic in Glenleith


Anxiety mounts in Glenleith as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of XDR tuberculosis, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent alarming surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of XDR tuberculosis.
Tuberculosis (TB) is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It spreads through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Symptoms include coughing (sometimes with blood), chest pain, fatigue, fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Residents of Glenleith experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Riverview in Glenleith noted a disturbing uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with XDR tuberculosis. Worries were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of XDR tuberculosis. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak hovers, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the escalating concerns, health officials have instigated several emergency protocols, and Glenleith have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Glenleith.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving no option unexplored in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Glenleith City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “While we cannot confirm the presence of an outbreak right now, we are responding to this issue with the highest degree of seriousness.”
The people in Glenleith have already begun to worry the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

Notable buildings in the city include Glenleith Castle, Glenleith Cathedral, and Lochaber Palace. Glenleith also has several museums and art galleries and a beautiful skyline. The Glenleith maritime festival is held annually in June, and tourists also flock to Glenleith to visit local breweries in autumn. Glenleith is also noted as a hub of local arts and culture, with Riverbend Hall and Crawford Comedy Club drawing in crowds for performances from local and international artists. Worries Over Possible Outbreak of Group A Streptococcus infection in Dalessie
25 February, 2025



The looming pandemic in Dalessie


Anxiety is rising in Dalessie as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of Group A Streptococcus infection, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent alarming surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of Group A Streptococcus infection.
Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is a bacterium often found in the throat and on the skin. It can cause a wide range of infections, from minor skin infections to severe diseases like strep throat, scarlet fever, and invasive group A streptococcal disease. It is usually spread through respiratory droplets or direct contact with an infected person. Residents of Dalessie experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Fairview in Dalessie noted a unsettling uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with Group A Streptococcus infection. Anxieties were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of Group A Streptococcus infection. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak dominates, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the expanding concerns, health officials have launched several emergency protocols, and Dalessie have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Dalessie.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are leaving no option unexplored in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Dalessie City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “Despite the lack of confirmation regarding an outbreak, we are treating this matter with the utmost gravity.”
The people in Dalessie have already begun to worry the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

Notable buildings in the city include Dalessie Castle, Dalessie Cathedral, and Benmore Hall. Dalessie also has botanical gardens with several greenhouses and a beautiful skyline. The Dalessie literary festival is held annually in May, and tourists also flock to Dalessie to sample the local cuisine in autumn. 23 February, 2025



The looming pandemic in Ardkeld


Anxiety mounts in Ardkeld as health officials investigate a potential outbreak of anthrax, raising alarm bells across the region. Though yet to be formally confirmed as a pandemic, suspicions have intensified following a recent troubling surge in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of anthrax.
Anthrax is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. It can occur in three forms: cutaneous (skin), inhalation, and gastrointestinal. Inhalation anthrax is the most lethal form and can be contracted by inhaling spores from contaminated animal products or bioterrorism. Symptoms vary depending on the type of infection but may include fever, fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Residents of Ardkeld experiencing any of these symptoms are advised to contact their GP or dial 111 for health advice.
In a press release, the director of the Riverview in Ardkeld noted a startling uptick in individuals reporting symptoms consistent with those associated with anthrax. Worries were first raised when the local GPs began reporting an unusual increase in patients with symptoms of anthrax. While investigations are still ongoing, the possibility of a pandemic outbreak dominates, prompting concern from health agencies.
In response to the expanding concerns, health officials have begun several contingency plans, and Ardkeld have convened an Emergency Pandemic Response Team, which will be meeting on 2025-02-28 and attempting to find solutions that will stop the spread of the pandemic in Ardkeld.
The First Minister assured residents that authorities are pursuing every lead in their efforts to safeguard public health, and furthermore urged residents to remain vigilant and cooperate with health directives from the Ardkeld City Council. A statement released by the First Minister’s office read: “Despite the lack of confirmation regarding an outbreak, we are treating this matter with the utmost gravity.”
The people in Ardkeld have already begun to weigh the possibility of a pandemic; potential consequences such as school closures, economic repercussions, and strain on healthcare resources, have sparked apprehension among residents, underscoring the need for swift and decisive action.

The Ardkeld opera festival is held annually in May, and tourists also flock to Ardkeld to take historical walking tours in autumn.
